Bright Data handles the hard stuff like JavaScript, proxies, and blocks. --- ### üßæ **SECTION 2: Extract & Save Insights** > **Purpose:** Process the scraped data and store it in a usable format (Google Sheets). #### üß± `Node 3: Extract Post Titles & Stats` **üîó Type:** HTML Extract **üß© What it does:** Takes the raw HTML from Quora and pulls out the meaningful information you care about: * üìù Question titles or post headlines * üîó URLs * üëç Vote count or engagement * üßë Author or answer snippet (if desired) You use **CSS Selectors or XPath** to tell n8n what to extract. For example: ```css a.q-box.qu-mb--tiny ‚Üí Post links div.q-relative ‚Üí Snippets or text ``` > üß† *Why it matters:* This is where raw data becomes structured. You‚Äôre now transforming messy HTML into useful, clean trend info. --- #### üìä `Node 4: Save Trends to Sheet` **üîó Type:** Google Sheets **üß© What it does:** Takes the structured trend data and **appends it to a Google Sheet** for archiving, analysis, or sharing. * üîÑ Keeps data centralized in Google Drive * üßæ Every entry becomes part of a monthly trend log * üì§ Can be exported, visualized, or emailed later > üí° *Why it matters:* This gives you a **living database of viral content** that you can reference later for reports, content ideas, social strategy, or client insights. --- ### üì¶ **Workflow Summary** | Section | What's Happening | Icons | | ------------------------------------ | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | -------- | | **üß† Section 1**
Trigger & Scrape | Automatically triggers each month ‚Üí sends request to scrape Quora via Bright Data | ‚è∞ üåê üîç | | **üßæ Section 2**

### üß† **SECTION 1: Trend Trigger & Scraper**

> **Purpose:** Automate the scraping of viral content from Quora every month.

#### ‚è∞ `Node 1: Monthly Trend Trigger`

**üîó Type:** Cron Scheduler
**üß© What it does:**
This node is like your personal assistant ‚Äî it **automatically starts the workflow on the 1st day of every month** without you lifting a finger.

* üóì Trigger schedule: Monthly (e.g., `0 0 1 * *`)
* üìà Use Case: Keeps your trend tracking consistent and timely

> üß† *Why it matters:* Instead of manually checking viral trends, this node ensures it‚Äôs **fully automated**, perfect for monthly reports or trend tracking dashboards.

---

#### üåê `Node 2: Scrape Quora Trends (Bright Data)`

**üîó Type:** HTTP Request
**üß© What it does:**
This node sends a **POST request to Bright Data** to scrape trending Quora results for a given topic (like `"https://www.quora.com/search?q=marketing"`).

* üîí Uses **Bright Data Web Unlocker** to bypass restrictions
* üß† Intelligent scraping with full HTML + rendering
* üîç Targets specific search terms (e.g., `marketing`, `UX`, `AI in marketing`)

> üí° *Why it matters:* You can collect **real trending content** from Quora without opening your browser. Bright Data handles the hard stuff like JavaScript, proxies, and blocks.

---

### üßæ **SECTION 2: Extract & Save Insights**

> **Purpose:** Process the scraped data and store it in a usable format (Google Sheets).

#### üß± `Node 3: Extract Post Titles & Stats`

**üîó Type:** HTML Extract
**üß© What it does:**
Takes the raw HTML from Quora and pulls out the meaningful information you care about:

* üìù Question titles or post headlines
* üîó URLs
* üëç Vote count or engagement
* üßë Author or answer snippet (if desired)

You use **CSS Selectors or XPath** to tell n8n what to extract. For example:

```css
a.q-box.qu-mb--tiny  ‚Üí  Post links  
div.q-relative  ‚Üí  Snippets or text  
```

> üß† *Why it matters:* This is where raw data becomes structured. You‚Äôre now transforming messy HTML into useful, clean trend info.

---

#### üìä `Node 4: Save Trends to Sheet`

**üîó Type:** Google Sheets
**üß© What it does:**
Takes the structured trend data and **appends it to a Google Sheet** for archiving, analysis, or sharing.
